Another non-newtonian fluid is oobleck. It also has similar properties. One of its properties being that if there is a lot of pressure applied to it, it acts like a solid, but if it is less pressure (or if the pressure is applied slowly), it acts as a liquid. You should maybe also check out Streets Science's video on it.

You would have loved the pigment dispersion I was making last year with fluorescent pigments. The articles were 10-20 microns so they were too large to have Brownian motion keep them from settling so I ended up using modified cellulose as a thickener to slow the settling. The result was exactly this but while mixing at 2000 rpm on our benchtop mixer. It was pretty cool to see fluorescent pink liquid climb up the mixing shaft.

One of my pet peeves is people equating “non Newtonian” with “shear thickening.” There are also “shear thinning” fluids that do the opposite, and they’re also non Newtonian. It’s like “linear” is newtonian, then there’s concave up and concave down for the other two. I forget what the axes are, and which one is which (concave up/down and shear thinning/thickening), but that’s actually the definition of those terms.
